title: Project 2: Seoul Bike Sharing Data Exploration
text:
First, we load the necessary libraries and the dataset. The dataset is ‘Seoul Bike Sharing Data’.
We’ll also clean up the column names for easier use and convert categorical variables into factors with more descriptive labels.

# Load libraries
library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.1     ✔ stringr   1.5.2
✔ ggplot2   4.0.0     ✔ tibble    3.3.0
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.1.0     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

library(lubridate)
library(knitr)

# Load data
bike_data_raw <- read_csv("./data/SeoulBikeData.csv", locale = locale(encoding = "latin1"))

Rows: 8760 Columns: 14
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr  (4): Date, Seasons, Holiday, Functioning Day
dbl (10): Rented Bike Count, Hour, Temperature(°C), Humidity(%), Wind speed ...

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

bike_data_raw

# A tibble: 8,760 × 14
   Date       `Rented Bike Count`  Hour `Temperature(°C)` `Humidity(%)`
   <chr>                    <dbl> <dbl>             <dbl>         <dbl>
 1 01/12/2017                 254     0              -5.2            37
 2 01/12/2017                 204     1              -5.5            38
 3 01/12/2017                 173     2              -6              39
 4 01/12/2017                 107     3              -6.2            40
 5 01/12/2017                  78     4              -6              36
 6 01/12/2017                 100     5              -6.4            37
 7 01/12/2017                 181     6              -6.6            35
 8 01/12/2017                 460     7              -7.4            38
 9 01/12/2017                 930     8              -7.6            37
10 01/12/2017                 490     9              -6.5            27
# ℹ 8,750 more rows
# ℹ 9 more variables: `Wind speed (m/s)` <dbl>, `Visibility (10m)` <dbl>,
#   `Dew point temperature(°C)` <dbl>, `Solar Radiation (MJ/m2)` <dbl>,
#   `Rainfall(mm)` <dbl>, `Snowfall (cm)` <dbl>, Seasons <chr>, Holiday <chr>,
#   `Functioning Day` <chr>

# Clean and prepare data
bike_data <- bike_data_raw |>
  janitor::clean_names() |>
  mutate(
    date = dmy(date),
    seasons = factor(seasons, levels = c("Spring", "Summer", "Autumn", "Winter")),
    holiday = factor(holiday, levels = c("No Holiday", "Holiday")),
    functioning_day = factor(functioning_day, levels = c("Yes", "No")),
    hour = factor(hour)
  )

head(bike_data)

# A tibble: 6 × 14
  date       rented_bike_count hour  temperature_c humidity_percent
  <date>                 <dbl> <fct>         <dbl>            <dbl>
1 2017-12-01               254 0              -5.2               37
2 2017-12-01               204 1              -5.5               38
3 2017-12-01               173 2              -6                 39
4 2017-12-01               107 3              -6.2               40
5 2017-12-01                78 4              -6                 36
6 2017-12-01               100 5              -6.4               37
# ℹ 9 more variables: wind_speed_m_s <dbl>, visibility_10m <dbl>,
#   dew_point_temperature_c <dbl>, solar_radiation_mj_m2 <dbl>,
#   rainfall_mm <dbl>, snowfall_cm <dbl>, seasons <fct>, holiday <fct>,
#   functioning_day <fct>

title: Project 2: Seoul Bike Sharing Data Exploration
text:
First, we load the necessary libraries and the dataset. The dataset is ‘Seoul Bike Sharing Data’.
We’ll also clean up the column names for easier use and convert categorical variables into factors with more descriptive labels.

# Load libraries
library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.1     ✔ stringr   1.5.2
✔ ggplot2   4.0.0     ✔ tibble    3.3.0
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.1.0

✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()

library(lubridate)
library(knitr)

# Load data
bike_data_raw <- read_csv("./data/SeoulBikeData.csv", locale = locale(encoding = "latin1"))

dbl (10): Rented Bike Count, Hour, Temperature(°C), Humidity(%), Wind speed ...

title: Project 2: Seoul Bike Sharing Data Exploration
text:
2. Numerical Summaries
Here we explore the data using numerical tables to understand distributions and relationships.

One-Way Contingency Tables

# Frequency of observations by Season
bike_data |>
  group_by(seasons) |>
  summarize(count = n())

# A tibble: 4 × 2
  seasons count
  <fct>   <int>
1 Spring   2208
2 Summer   2208
3 Autumn   2184
4 Winter   2160




Two-Way Contingency Tables

# Season and Holiday
bike_data |>
  group_by(seasons, holiday) |>
  summarize(count = n())

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'seasons'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.


# A tibble: 8 × 3
# Groups:   seasons [4]
  seasons holiday    count
  <fct>   <fct>      <int>
1 Spring  No Holiday  2136
2 Spring  Holiday       72
3 Summer  No Holiday  2160
4 Summer  Holiday       48
5 Autumn  No Holiday  2064
6 Autumn  Holiday      120
7 Winter  No Holiday  1968
8 Winter  Holiday      192




Summaries of Quantitative Variables
Here, we calculate summary statistics (mean, median, standard deviation) for quantitative variables, grouped by the seasons and holiday variable.

bike_data |>
  group_by(seasons, holiday) |>
  summarize(
    across(
      where(is.numeric),
      list(
        mean = ~ mean(.x, na.rm = TRUE),
        median = ~ median(.x, na.rm = TRUE),
        sd = ~ sd(.x, na.rm = TRUE)
      ),
      .names = "{.col}_{.fn}"
    )
  )

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'seasons'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.


# A tibble: 8 × 29
# Groups:   seasons [4]
  seasons holiday    rented_bike_count_mean rented_bike_count_median
  <fct>   <fct>                       <dbl>                    <dbl>
1 Spring  No Holiday                   733.                     586.
2 Spring  Holiday                      635.                     366.
3 Summer  No Holiday                  1034.                     904.
4 Summer  Holiday                     1022.                     925 
5 Autumn  No Holiday                   823.                     768 
6 Autumn  Holiday                      758.                     632 
7 Winter  No Holiday                   232.                     212 
8 Winter  Holiday                      157.                     138 
# ℹ 25 more variables: rented_bike_count_sd <dbl>, temperature_c_mean <dbl>,
#   temperature_c_median <dbl>, temperature_c_sd <dbl>,
#   humidity_percent_mean <dbl>, humidity_percent_median <dbl>,
#   humidity_percent_sd <dbl>, wind_speed_m_s_mean <dbl>,
#   wind_speed_m_s_median <dbl>, wind_speed_m_s_sd <dbl>,
#   visibility_10m_mean <dbl>, visibility_10m_median <dbl>,
#   visibility_10m_sd <dbl>, dew_point_temperature_c_mean <dbl>, …
